author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: 'I don't care' driver arrested after swerving into couple
text:
Does he care now?
The Texas driver who was caught on video callously saying "I don't care" after swerving into two people on a motorcycle and seriously injuring one of them has been arrested.
William Crum, 68, faces two counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon, a second-degree felony, following Saturday's wreck near Granbury. He was in custody pending a bond hearing on Tuesday.
Crum, who faces two to 20 years in prison for each count, initially claimed he was distracted by a wasp sting, but later said it was a spider who caused the accident.
"All of the sudden, I felt this stinging in my left leg," he told NBC on Monday , before his arrest. "I didn't try to hurt anybody. It was a reflex from the pain."
Hood County Sheriff's Office William Crum faces two counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon, However, Crum could provide no evidence of the sting, according to CBS .
"I knew he was coming to hit me. He hit me on purpose," Eric Sanders told NBC. "I don't care what he said, I don't care what his explanation is. I almost died; my girlfriend is upstairs with the possibility of having her arm amputated because of this."
The video, recorded by a rider behind Sanders, clearly shows Crum crossing a double yellow center line and swerving into Sanders and Debra Simpson as they tried to pass his car.
The couple had attempted to pass the car because Crum was only going 40 miles per hour in a 60-mph zone, Sanders said.
Eric Sanders via Facebook Crum appeared to intentionally swerve and hit two people on motorcycle on Texas road. Eric Sanders via Facebook A woman was seriously injured in the accident. Eric Sanders via Facebook The driver repeatedly said 'I don't care' following the accident. Previous Next Enlarge Sanders walked away relatively unscathed, but Simpson suffered a broken wrist and deep arm lacerations, and is facing a two-week hospital stay in Fort Worth with the possibility of amputation.
The video, posted on Sanders' Facebook page, has been viewed a staggering four million times.
